Î¼ÎµÏ„á½° Ï„Î¿á¿¦ Ï€Î½ÎµÏÎ¼Î±Ï„Î¿Ï‚ á½‘Î¼á¿¶Î½. á¼ˆÎ¼Î®Î½.Î±Î¼Î·Î½ f35 â„µC [98%] RP,HF,OC,TR,CP Â¦ --- (ğ•»87)A,048v [2%] NU,The citation of f35 is based on thirty-six MSSâ€”18, 35, 201, 204, 328, 386, 394, 444, 604, 757, 824, 928, 959, 986, 1072, 1075, 1100, 1247, 1249, 1503, 1548, 1637, 1725, 1732, 1761, 1768, 1855, 1864, 1865, 1876, 1892, 2080, 2466, 2554, 2587 and 2723â€”all of which I collated myself. All except 328, 394, 959, 986, 1892 and 2080 are â€˜perfectâ€™ representatives of f35 in Philemon, as they stand, the others having a single variant each. The uniformity is impressive. Since these MSS come from all over the Mediterranean world (Sinai, Jerusalem, Patmos, Constantinople, Bucharest, Aegean, Trikala, Athens, Mt. Athos [seven different monasteries], Grottaferrata, Vatican, etc.) they are certainly representative of the family, giving us the precise family profileâ€”it is reflected in the Text without exception.In the statements of evidence I have included the percentage of manuscript attestation for each variant, within either ( ) or [ ]. I have used ( ) for the evidence taken from TuT, which I take to be reasonably precise. For the variant sets that are not covered there I had to revert to von Soden and the apparatus of N-A27, supplementing from other sources where possible (Scrivener and Tischendorf)â€”the percentages offered, I have used [ ] for these, are extrapolations based on a comparison of these sources.I venture to predict, if complete collations ever become available, that for any non-Byzantine variants listed with 5 to 1% support (in my apparatus) the margin of error should not exceed Â±1%; for non-Byzantine variants listed with 10 to 6% support the margin of error should hardly exceed Â±3%; where there is some division among the Byzantine witnesses the margin of error should rarely exceed Â±15%. However, I guarantee the witness of Family 35. Please see the last footnote for Matthew for further information.
